page.title: 03MARKET RASEN-LOCAL HISTORY 2
page.content: There was a steady increase in population(480 in early 16th century). A major change came in 1780 when the old two arable field system with pasture was replaced by 97 plots with hedges. After enclosure the town was able to expand from merely a cluster of clay-walled houses by spreading on to the common land and also along the Louth turnpike road.The town continued to be a centre for the agriculture of the area and the coming of the railway in 1848 increased the importance of the market and thus the town. Charles Dickens described Market Rasen as 'the second sleepiest town in all England' but by 1900 the town boasted maltings, mills,two corn exchanges, a railway station and other important amenities. Today the town retains its market and the cattle market and is the focus of the surrounding countryside.
